caseTitle: NANA OFOR! ATTA II, v NANA BONSRA AGYEI,
summary: This civil appeal before the West African Court of Appeal, Gold Coast, arose from a land dispute involving the Muronam Stool and the Banka Stool, where a prior judgment had already determined title. The current plaintiffs were the Omanhene of Akim Abuakwa (paramount chief) and the Odikro of Muronam (sub-chief). The trial court dismissed their claim based on estoppel, citing a 1940 judgment against the Muronam Stool in a previous suit with the Banka Stool over the same land. On appeal, the court upheld the estoppel: the second plaintiff (Muronam Stool) was directly bound by the prior judgment. The first plaintiff (Akim Abuakwa) was held estopped by conduct, as it had knowledge of the prior proceedings through its sub-chief and officials, shared the same interest in upholding Muronam’s title, and failed to intervene despite having the right and duty to do so. The court emphasized that Akim Abuakwa’s interest derived solely from Muronam’s title, making it privy to that party. Thus, both plaintiffs were barred from re-litigating the issue of title.
verdict: Appeal dismissed. The plaintiffs were estopped from re-litigating the title to the land due to prior judgment and conduct.

rationaleHighlights: Second plaintiff estopped due to prior final judgment against them on same land title issue.
First plaintiff, though not formal party, is privy to second plaintiff via allegiance and dependent title claim.
First plaintiff had knowledge of prior suit and duty to intervene but chose to stand by, constituting estoppel by conduct.
Interest in land derived through sub-stool's title; paramountcy does not confer independent ownership.
Judgment in rem binds parties and privies, preventing re-litigation of same issue.
